summary: This is a psychology services memorandum from the Metropolitan Correctional Center in New York summarizing all psychological contacts with inmate Jeffrey Epstein from his arrival on July 8, 2019, through August 8, 2019. It details his placement on and removal from suicide watch, his psychological assessments, and his reported concerns while in custody.

events.title: Epstein's Intake and Initial Suicide Watch Order
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein arrived at the Metropolitan Correctional Center and was seen for an intake screening. The Chief Psychologist spoke with Central Office and determined he should be placed on suicide watch due to increased risk factors.

events.title: First Suicide Risk Assessment
events.description: Mr. Epstein was seen for a suicide risk assessment where he denied any suicide ideation, intention, or plan. He was removed from suicide watch and placed on psychology observation.

events.title: Incident with String Around Neck
events.description: At approximately 2am, the on-call psychologist was contacted by the Operations Lieutenant indicating Mr. Epstein was being placed on suicide watch as he was found with a string hanging around his neck. According to the log book, he told staff his cellmate tried to kill him.

events.title: Removal from Suicide Watch
events.description: Mr. Epstein was removed from suicide watch and placed on psychology observation. It was observed he had a scar around his neck, which was scaring over. He continued to insist he did not know what happened.

events.title: Court Note on Suicidal Tendencies
events.description: Mr. Epstein was seen for another suicide risk assessment after returning from court with a note from the court indicating 'suicidal tendencies.' He denied he was suicidal.

locations: Metropolitan Correctional Center, New York, New York
keyFacts: Jeffrey Epstein was placed on suicide watch upon his arrival at the Metropolitan Correctional Center on July 8, 2019, due to risk factors including his sex offense charge, high-profile case, and pretrial status.

On July 23, 2019, Epstein was found with a string hanging around his neck, leading to his placement back on suicide watch. He later told staff his cellmate tried to kill him, but during assessments claimed he could not remember the incident, at one point attributing it to 'sleep apnea.'

A note from the court on August 1, 2019, indicated Epstein had 'suicidal tendencies,' but during a subsequent assessment he denied being suicidal, stated suicide was against his religion, and emphasized he was fighting his case.
Throughout the documented period, Epstein repeatedly requested to be moved to general population and to be celled alone if housed in SHU, requests that were not granted.

The memorandum documents a pattern of Epstein denying any psychological concerns, suicidal ideation, or mental health history during official assessments, while reporting correctional issues like noise, lack of a spoon, and wearing an orange jumpsuit.
